_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
Enterprise Kutz Terminal & Storage
Risk Management Plan (RMP)
Executive Summary

At the Enterprise Kutz Terminal and Storage, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.

The Enterprise Kutz Terminal and Storage is owned by Enterprise Terminals & Storage, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Mapletree, LLC and operated by Enterprise Products Operating,LLC.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help provide for the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation and the processes involved
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
* Emergency Response Programs
* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Kutz Terminal that are regulated by EPAA¿s RMP rule.  

Facility Description

The Kutz Terminal is a natural gas liquid (NGL) pipeline system, mixed NGL storage and unloading facility.  The tank storage facility is covered by Federal Regulation 40 CFR Part 68.   We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 1 facility since there are no receptors within the calculated worst case distance.  Additionally, there have been no incidents with offsite conseequences in the last five years,

and emergency response activities are coordinated with the local emergency response agencies.

The Kutz Terminal has a single Department of Transportation regulated pipeline that is routed from the storage tank at the facility and injects into the mixed NGL pipeline.  This pipeline contains mixed NGL (natural gasoline,iso-pentane, normal pentane, normal butane, iso-butane, propane and ethane).  The Kutz storage tank is a single pressure vessel that receives mixed NGL from the transport truck unloading docks at the site.  This tank is used as a holding tank for subsequent injection of the mixed liquid product into the mixed NGL pipeline.  The tank level is administratively controlled to hold and not exceed 90% of its capacity.

In our process we use the following hazardous materials that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

No toxic materials to report.

Flammables

Mixed NGL is received from transport trucks and is delivered into the storage tank.  This material from the tank is pumped into the mixed NGL product pipeline for transportation to the other facilities for fractionation.

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenario(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.

Worst Case Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no regulated toxic chemicals to report for the Hobbs Terminal.

Alternate Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no regulated toxic chemicals to report for the Hobbs Terminal.

Worse Case Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

This simulation involves the rupture or failure of the storage tank

resulting in a simulated vapor cloud explosion.  The NGL storage tank is administratively controlled at a maximum 90% full level when in use, and typically contains less than this maximum quantity due to the receipt of NGL's via individual tank trucks.  The maximum 90% full quantity is reported in the data elements as the worst case quantity.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the reporting section of the Risk Management Plan

Alternate Case Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

Kutz Terminal and Storage is registered as an RMP Program 1 facility with flammables only.  Reporting of an alternate case scenario is not required by the regulation.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The following is a summary of the accidental release revention program in place at Kutz Terminal and Storage.  The process at the facility is regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation (Program 1).  Release prevention is provided through the use of written operating procedures, employee training in written procedures, including normal operation and emergency release procedures, and in the design of safety and release prevention equipment installed at the terminal site.  In addition, a written safety program designed to comply with all applicable OSHA safety performance regulations is strictly enforced at all Enterprise facilities, including the Kutz Terminal and Storage facility.  As part of the Enterprise safety program, the terminal utilizes procedures that are included in the Enterprise program, but may not specifically be required at non-PSM and/or RMP Program 1 facilities (e.g. Safe work practice training; safe work permitting and hot work permitting).

Emergency Response Program

Enterprise maintains an

Integrated Contingency Plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning and reporting.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the New Mexico State Police, District 10, which includes the San Juan County Sheriff's Department, the local Bloomfield Police department, Fire Department, and Emergency Medical Service.

In the event of an accidental release, local Enterprise personnel are trained to sound the alarm, shut off the source from a safe location or activate the emergency shutdown system, contact Enterprise Operations Control and secure the area.  Enterprise Operations Control in turn notifies San Juan Emergency Management, the New Mexico State Police and local Fire Departments.  Remote activation can also be accomplished from the Operations Control center which is based in Houston, Texas.  In addition, there are local gas detection systems that alarm locally and in Houston Control.  If these detectors annunciate, the facility can be shutdown remotely from Houston Control or locally by operations personnel.    

Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The following is a list of reviews and/or improvements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental hazardous material releases:

*  There are currently no changes planned for the facility that would improve safety.
